Note:  Pose will be the same as the Friday 4-hour sessions, so if you want to get a REALLY long pose, sign up for both.  

Jeremy Durling will host- Jeremy's paintings are available through the Sloane Merrill Gallery on Charles Street in Boston.  

Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $55, non-members for $70.    Three hours each Saturday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at

http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html


PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $55 or $65 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.

results.description:
A great intro session if you want to find ways to conquer your fear. But still a great oppy for return guests to practice . 


If weeknights are difficult, take advantage of this Saturday meetup to build confident speaking skills. We'll show you a few secrets to defeat the anxiety we all feel in front of groups, and some tips to connect with your audience. [We'll be meeting most First Saturdays unless a holiday moves us to the preceding weekend].


Our Meetups are fast-paced and entertaining. Not intimidating. You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meetups run. [This session will supplement our usual Wed evening meeting, not replace it. Sessions start promptly, so please arrive a bit early.]  Please rsvp.

4th Floor, Room 034. You must take the elevator by the security desk to access the floor.

Parking: If you can't find street parking, there is parking to the rear of the bldg. You will present your ticket to the security desk on your way out ($3), then insert the ticket at the gate as you exit.
(Don't park in the supermarket/Porter Square shopping center parking lot.)


See the "About Us" tab for more info.


NOTE: For those who like to plan ahead, we'll be meeting the 2nd and 4th Wednesdays in March.  We'll hold a First [or Second] Saturday session in April, as well.

results.description:
Photoshop has become the de-facto editing tool for serious photographers looking to get creative with their photographs. 

Join us for this in depth one day introduction that will get you using photoshop in no time at all.

This workshop focuses solely on the things photographers need to know. It walks you through key skills like: 

MORNING SESSION

The camera raw interface and its tools

Exposure adjustments

Sharpening

Color balancing and black and white conversions 

Selections and crops 

AFTERNOON SESSION 

understanding Layers

brushes and blend modes 

Replacing backgrounds with blend modes and brushes 

Speeding up your workflow with actions and camera raw presets.

The sessions will be as jargon free and made as simple as possible. 

the class is just   $120 for the whole day. 

YOU ONLY NEED A NOTEPAD AND PEN FOR THIS CLASS. 

While you are welcome to bring a laptop to follow along, experience tells us that doing so can interfere with your ability to pay close attention.  No accommodation will be made for those who have issues on their laptop. The class will not stop while you fix your issue nor will sections be repeated if you miss the topic because of  laptop issues.

results.description:
Time for the first all-day Quarterly of 2016! All-day open gaming from 10AM to midnight at Courtyard Marriott in Natick around the corner from the Natick/Route 30 exit off the Pike and next to the Natick Collection (Mall). Anyone of game-playing age who is interested in playing board games is welcome.

The Quarterly will take place in the Commons and Walden function rooms at the hotel. Yes, two function rooms for this one! I believe the Commons will be able to seat approximately 120 and 42 in the Walden for a total of 162 seats. Get all your friends on board and let’s try to outgrow these rooms too!

=============

Commons Room

=============

The Commons room is a large function room the size of most of the rooms we have used for previous Quarterlies. This will be where the bulk of the open gaming will occur.

=============

Walden Room

=============

The Walden room is a smaller function room and will be able to seat approximately 25. This room will be reserved for scheduled games, scheduled teaching games, and games that need a quieter space away from the rumble and outbursts of the large open gaming area in the Commons. Please, play party games in the Commons instead of the Walden.

===============

Room Layout (Draft)

===============

Here is the room layout that I have instructed the hotel to work with.  It is not final, because I was just informed that part of the Commons is shaped a bit different.  All of the tables should  still fit, but I am not going to know for sure until the day of the event.  Also, the water station in the lobby will be moved to counter space available inside the Commons.

The layout of the Walden is final.

============================

Pre-Registration (Online Registration)

============================

You purchase your pre-registrations for $8 per person at:

https://squareup.com/market/TGA/tga-q-all-day-quarterly-pre-registration-2

After check-out, your name and/or e-mail address will be added to the pre-registration list. When checking in at the event at the door, just mention that you pre-registered. If purchasing multiple pre-registrations, list all the names you are purchasing pre-registrations for during check-out in the "Write a note to the seller" field. Pre-registrations will only be available until 1PM on March 4th, the day before the event.

================

At-Door Registration

================

Registration at the door costs $10 per person. In addition to cash, you will now also be able to pay with debit and credit cards at the door.

==========================

What does the Quarterly look like?

==========================

Here are photos of what our last Quarterly looked like: http://www.meetup.com/TabletopGamersAlliance/photos/26717564/

=======

Parking

=======

The Courtyard has a small lot in front of the lobby, but there is another lot on the opposite side of the building with ample parking for everyone.

=========================

Traveling from Boston (sans car)

=========================

If you are traveling from the Boston area and are without car, there are a couple of ways that you can still attend our event.

• Several TGA members with cars live in various parts around the city. You may be able to arrange a carpool with one of them if you leave a comment below requesting a carpool. Should anyone be able to help, then you two will be able to work out the details via private messages here.

• Another option is to travel to the Natick commuter rail station and then call a cab/Uber to bring you to the hotel.

========

Beverages

========

There will be water stations set up in both function rooms and the hotel bistro will serve coffee in the morning. With it being a hotel, there should be beverage vending machines around too.

The hotel bar will be open for service from 5PM - 7PM.  Attendees who buy drinks from the bar are allowed to take them anywhere inside the hotel, including back to the function rooms for gaming.  In accordance with the open container law and the terms of the hotel's liquor license, you are not allowed to transport your drinks outside of the building.

This has never been a problem with our group, but it should be known that our contract with the venue contains a clause prohibiting anyone from bringing in outside alcohol.

======

Dining

======

The hotel bistro serves breakfast and will have special hours for lunch (noon - 2PM) and for dinner (5PM - 8PM).  It will be the most convenient food option to get you back to gaming ASAP.

The hotel bistro has also put together a special menu to expand their offerings during our event:

• Sandwiches or Wraps choice of, Turkey, Roast Beef, Tuna, and Chicken Caesar Wrap with Drink, Brownie or Cookie and chips- $12.95

• Bistro Burger, Drink, Brownie or Cookie and Chips- $11.25

• Slice of Cheese or Pepperoni pizza, Drink and Chips- $4.95


• Flatbread Pizza, Drink and Chips - $11.45


• Chicken Wings(6) with Drink and Chips- $11.45

The hotel lounge has seated service and a different menu than the bistro for dinner.

For off-site food options, the venue is located next to the Natick Mall with its multiple food courts and restaurants along with the multitude of restaurants within the mall’s immediate vicinity. With options from ranging from Taco Bell to Legal Seafood and everything in-between, this Quarterly will have more refueling options available than any previous Quarterly ever!

Generally, hotel function rooms have a no-outside food policy.  However, it should be fine to bring in snacks and such, but please refrain from bringing in delivery or take-out.

=========================================

You guys can also discuss which games to bring/play in the comments below.

RSVP's are not required for this event, but are very much appreciated so that we can gauge whether the facilities we have rented are sufficient for the demand.
results.name: All-Day Quarterly (2016Q1)

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

results.description:
FOR THIS EVENT, WE ARE USING EVENTBRITE TO RSVP. CHECK IT OUT HERE. THANKS!

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/codeacross-boston-2016-tickets-20590413481

---

Please join Code for Boston for a weekend of civic hacking, youth mentorship, and code education at our third annual CodeAcross event on March 5-6, 2015 at the Roxbury Innovation Center. Our goal for this year's CodeAcross is to start building the next generation of civic hackers through a curated, educational hackathon. Pretty cool, right?!

To do this, Code for Boston is partnering with Resilient Coders, a code education non-profit focused on underserved youth, on what we're calling a progression hackathon: a structured hacking event where novice coders and students work in teams with experienced software developers and designers on hacakathon projects, and learn fundamental dev skills like ideation and wireframing, Github and source control, and more through a series of fast-paced, educational workshops.

At CodeAcross, we'll bring together civic technologists, community organizations, and local businesses to work collaboratively on projects around career building, equity, and economic development. Although this year's event is more focused on technology than our usual events, CodeAcross will always be open to the entire community: Community involvement and inclusion are extremely important to us, and our best projects always have a mix of technical and non-technical team members.

We can't wait to see you all for a couple days of learning, teaching, collaborating, and civic hacking!

CodeAcross would not be possible without the generosity of the following organizations:


http://photos.prnewswire.com/prnvar/20130910/SF76762LOGO

results.description:
(a set of 6 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is six linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes (Mar 5, 12, 19, Apr 2, 9 and 16.  There is no class on the weekend of Mar 26) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)

results.description:
Hi all, 

A friend of mine from back home recently has been diagnosed with a condition known as cardiomyopathy, and has been given a Left Ventricle Assist Device or LVAD to aid her heart function until she receives a heart transplant. 

This Halloween, we will be hosting a costume-themed charity workout to show our support for Olivia, and raise money for her various medical and living expenses. To fully understand why we are hosting this charity, you must first understand her story:

From her sister, Sofia Hart:

"Olivia always thrived to do the best she could. Being gifted with horse back riding as our hobby (or life passion) growing up, she was incredibly fearless and passionate with everything in her. She was also happy to be a Vineyarder during her years playing Hockey and Soccer, representing the place she loved most, home. Her determination was unstoppable on and off horse back, the field, and the ice. These characteristics followed her through her life growing into adulthood. 

As a recent University of Vermont graduate, she did just the same in her studies. When she felt defeated, she would do everything in her power to figure out what went wrong, and how she could fix her mistakes. While at her graduation, tears of joy were brought to my eyes as she smiled receiving her achievements and laughed and hugged with friends. Not only was she proud of herself, but she was even more proud of the people who surrounded her and their accomplishments too.

These qualities and characteristics went even further into the workplace. As a former employee of the Homeport Resturant, she used the skills and experience she learned there and carried it to the Seafood Shanty. Each and every job she has held has meant so much to her. Good days and bad days, she always would talk so highly of her job, especially for how dedicated she was to each establishment. 

Through hardwork, fearlessness, dedication and most importantly, love, Olivia has gained a rather admirable reputation growing up on Martha's Vineyard for 22 years, and at UVM during her college years. 

These amazing qualities and characteristics have not diminished one bit during these tough times. Her spirit is incredibly high, and she shocks us on a daily basis how positive her attitude is. I can not imagine being in her place, and handling the news she gets on a daily basis. Although she has received bad news many times, her positive outlook has not changed. Olivia is determined as ever, looking toward the brightest future."

Here is more on Olivias condition, with a post from her Facebook page:

"So here it is. On the 9th I was transported to Massachusetts General Hospital and diagnosed with a condition known as cardiomyopathy which is a disease of the heart muscle. There is damage to both the right and left portions but the majority of the damage is in the left ventricle. It wasn't until I had a cardiac MRI that the doctors realized my condition was most likely irreversible. The doctors believe it either began years ago when I most likely contracted a viral infection that attacked my heart or may have been something I was born with... the overall cause is unknown. My age enabled me to live and thrive with the condition until a couple of months ago. Currently, I am in the process of being placed on the heart transplant list, which I will hopefully be accepted to by the end of the week, and will receive a new heart by the start of the new year. For now that is about all that we know."

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Gary Deines

results.description:
There is really good exhibition at The Rose Art Museum at Brandeis that would be great to as a group of art lovers and then discuss afterwards. The Rose is a premier art museum too. It's free to the public!
http://www.brandeis.edu/rose/onview/spring2016/rosalyndrexler.html

Here's more:

An historic, monographic exhibition, Who Does She Think She Is? is a long-overdue retrospective of Rosalyn Drexler’s multidisciplinary practice. Showcasing Drexler’s major paintings and collages as well as her captivating early sculptures, award winning plays and novels, and photographic and video documentation of the artist’s wild and varied theatrical career, the exhibition is co-curated by Rose Curator-at-Large Katy Siegel and Curatorial Assistant Caitlin Julia Rubin.

Drexler has been an active participant in New York’s artistic scene, and her collages and large format paintings—which borrow imagery from movies, advertisements, and newspapers of the 1960s—reverberate with the Pop art of her contemporaries. Yet Drexler’s work unfolds personal and social conflict with a political consciousness rare in the cool art of that moment and an explicitness that fearlessly courts vulgarity. A vivid portrait of both Drexler’s singular artistic persona and the artistic circles of which she was a vibrant and fluid part, Who Does She Think She Is? shows Drexler to be both a sharp critic of and a joyful participant in American culture of the past 50 years.
results.name: New Exhibit at the Rose Art Museum & Discussion

Our past experience is that 20% of the RSVP shows up in the weekend meetings. Considering that, unless we have about 50 RSVPs, we cannot have a face to face meeting. Please use the questions / answers / discussions below for now. While asking questions, please make reference to the name of the course and the related module within the course. 

Cousera offers the following classes towards obtaining highly valuable knowledge/skills in Data Science Specialization. It is sometimes hard to work on the exercises and homework without the help of an expert.  Receiving one-on-one help from an expert can improve the commitment of finishing the program with accelerated learning. results.description:
Join us along with founder and developer of Your Privilege is Showing, Lillian Medville, as we have fun playtesting this social justice card game that is nearing completion. 

In Lillian's words...

What it is: 

You're Privilege Is Showing is a social justice card game focusing on sexism, racism and privilege that is currently in development. To learn more, check out the website: http://www.yourprivilegeisshowing.com/ 

What you should bring: 

Bring your shiny self, your willingness to try new things, your patience, and your ability to give excellent feedback.

What you should expect: 

We will have you sign a non-disclosure agreement (basically saying you won't learn about the game, then run off and make your own game just like it). Then we will explain the rules and play the game. Afterwards we'll ask you to fill out a short questionnaire to help us improve it.

If you have any questions let us know at <a>[masked]</a>

--

When this blows up like Cards Against Humanity and helps us save the world, you can brag that you were there to help make it happen!
results.name: Your Privilege is Showing-- Playtesting for Justice!

results.description:
We're doing a fun 10-week training program! All levels are welcome, and you don't need to be able to make it every week. In week 1, we timed ourselves in a few key events (e.g. 100 freestyle), and now we're doing a training program to get ourselves faster. At the end of 10 weeks we'll time ourselves again and see how much we've improved! If you can't make a week, don't worry, you can still come to the other weeks.


The 10 weeks will include clinics on technique, flip turns, and any special requests, as well as some good sets to get us swimming faster. If there's a race you're targeting and want to work on that distance or event, let us know and we can help tailor the workouts for you.

We go across the street for pizza (or other food if you don't eat pizza) every week after the swim. Save time to join us! We usually finish up by about 4:30pm.


---------------


The pool opens at 2pm, so we meet to go in at 1:45 so that we can be out on the pool deck by 2. $6 to get in, Cambridge residents $5 (or you can buy a 10-pack for an approximate 10% discount, and we do these weekly so you'll have the opportunity to use them up).

Street parking is available but stressful, and the 69 bus drops off down the block, or you can bike or run there and do 2/3 of a triathlon :)

results.description:
All dates, times, and locations are listed below. There are 2 days with multiple times and locations. Your choice.

Get your free tickets now threw Eventbrite NOW.


Taste of Iceland returns to Boston March 4-7 to celebrate various aspects of Icelandic culture. Bostonians will have the opportunity to experience authentic Icelandic cuisine, rock out at the famed Reykjavik Calling concert, view and discuss Icelandic film, learn how Iceland’s inspiring writers around the world and more during this four-day festival. RSVP on Facebook, join the conversation on Twitter and Instagram by tagging @IcelandNatural with #TasteofIceland and keep checking this page for updated information.

Icelandic Menu at The Merchant

Icelandic Menu at The Merchant | March 4-7
Icelandic chef Thrainn Freyr Vigfússon, head chef at Blue Lagoon’s LAVA Restaurant, will fly to Boston to collaborate with American chef Matt Foley, Executive Chef at The Merchant. Thrainn has won numerous awards and is currently the coach of the Icelandic Culinary Team. Known for his innovative approach and talent, Thrainn is a leading authority in Iceland's culinary world. He was named Icelandic Chef of the Year in 2007 and was awarded the silver medal for Scandinavian Chef of the Year in 2009. He will bring Icelandic cuisine to The Merchant’s kitchen and work with Foley to create a cohesive (and delicious!) menu. Signature Reyka Vodka and Brennivin cocktails will be served; view the drink menu here!

WHEN: Friday, March 4 - Monday, March 7
WHERE: The Merchant | 60 Franklin St, Boston, MA 02110
RESERVATIONS: Online or (617)[masked]
MENU: Four-course menu | Signature cocktails
COST: $65

Reykjavik Calling

Reykjavik Calling | March 5
​Taste of Iceland’s famous Reykjavik Calling concert returns to The Middle East on Saturday, March 5. This year’s lineup features Icelandic bands Axel Flóvent and Ceasetone, with additional performances by local bands Adam Ezra Group and Nemes. Reykjavik Calling in Boston is sponsored by WERS and Iceland Naturally. Admission is free on a first-come, first-served basis. Must be 21+.

WHEN: Saturday, March 5 | Doors open at 8:00pm | Concert begins at 9:00pm
WHERE: The Middle East | 472 - 480 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge, MA 02139
COST: Free
RSVP: Eventbrite
FEATURED ARTISTS:
Axel Flóvent (Iceland): Facebook | Twitter | Soundcloud | Instagram
Ceasetone (Iceland): Website | Facebook | Twitter | Soundcloud | Instagram
Adam Ezra Group (Boston): Website | Facebook | Twitter | Soundcloud | Instagram
Nemes (Boston): Website | Facebook | Twitter | Soundcloud | Instagram

Rock in Reykjavik

Screening of Icelandic Film “Rokk í Reykjavik” (Rock in Reykjavik) | March 6​
Join Iceland Naturally for a screening of Rokk í Reykjavik, a documentary that explores the expanding rock scene in Iceland. The film features a variety of performances and interviews with well-known rock stars from 1981-1982. The screening at the Brattle Theatre in Cambridge is first-come, first-served. Afterward, join Sigtryggur Baldursson, managing director of the Iceland Music Export, for a Q & A session to learn more about the film and the current music scene in Iceland.

WHEN: Sunday, March 6 | 3:00pm
WHERE: The Brattle Theatre | 40 Brattle St, Cambridge, MA 02138
COST: Free
RSVP: Eventbrite


The Write Stuff

The Write Stuff: Why Iceland Inspires Us to Put Pen to Paper | March 5
This literary event celebrates Iceland’s robust storytelling culture with a discussion lead by Eliza Reid, a Reykjavik-based writer and editor who helped found the Iceland Writers Retreat, an annual gathering for published and aspiring writers. Iceland is one of the most popular destinations for creative minds, and Reid will focus her talk on what makes Iceland so inspirational for lovers of the written word. Attendees can learn about, discuss and purchase novels from highly-acclaimed Icelandic authors. Attend The Write Stuff and share your experiences from the event using #TasteofIceland and #IcelandWriters for the chance to win a signed copy of Bloodhoof!
WHEN: Saturday, March 5 | 1:00-2:30pm
WHERE: Prudential Center Barnes and Noble | 800 Boylston St #179, Boston, MA 02199
COST: Free
RSVP: Eventbrite

About Taste of Iceland
Taste of Iceland in Boston is presented by Iceland Naturally in cooperation with Icelandair, Reyka Vodka, Blue Lagoon, Visit Reykjavik, Icelandic Glacial, Promote Iceland, Ölgerðin Egill Skallagrímsson, Iceland Airwaves, The Merchant, The Middle East, WERS and Brattle Theatre.

About Iceland Naturally
Iceland Naturally is a cooperative marketing organization that promotes the tourism, services, products and culture of Iceland. Through events, promotions, and online marketing initiatives, Iceland Naturally introduces Iceland’s creativity and natural wonders to North Americans. The group is comprised of Icelandair, Icelandic Group, Islandsbanki, Reyka Vodka, City of Reykjavik, Icelandic Glacial Water, Blue Lagoon, Keflavik International Airport (KEF), Landsvirkjun, Ölgerðin Egill Skallagrímsson, Promote Iceland and the Government of Iceland.

results.description:
Women's Community League of Weston sponsors a special and FREE screening of The Amazing Nina Simone followed by a conversation with filmmaker Jeff Lieberman.

Documentary directed by Jeff L. Lieberman

Runtime: 110 minutes

Released in USA, 2015

Nina Simone nee Eunice Waymon, was left out of Civil Rights history, erased by jazz critics, and forgotten by most Americans because no one knew how to categorize her greatness.  But throughout the 1960s, Nina Simone was both loved and feared for her outspoken vision of Black Freedom.  Her musical proclamations like "Mississippi Goddam", and her iconic style gave voice to people of all colors facing oppression, and continues to empower today with its unrelenting appeal for justice. Today, Nina is more popular eleven years after her death than ever before. President Barack Obama listed ‘Sinnerman’ in his top 5 favorite songs, and whether re-mixed, re-sampled or in its pure form, Nina’s music continues to empower people around the world with its unrelenting appeal for justice. Now the story of America's most overlooked musical genius is finally brought to light in the acclaimed new documentary film, “The Amazing Nina Simone.”

Director Jeff L. Lieberman (”Re-Emerging: The Jews of Nigeria”) brings audiences on Nina’s journey from the segregated South, through the worlds of classical music, jazz joints & international concert halls. Navigating through the twists & turns of the 1960’s fight for racial equality, the film delves deep into Nina’s artistry and intentions, and is told through over 50 exclusive and intimate interviews with the people who knew Nina best: her friends, family, musicians and fellow activists. Eric Burdon (The Animals), Sam Waymon (Nina’s Brother & Longtime Band Member), Nikki Giovanni (Poet, Professor & Friend) & Marie Christine Dunham-Pratt (Nina's Lover & Friend) are just a few of the people who answer long-held questions behind Nina's most beloved songs, bold style, controversial statements, and the reason she left America.

Seating is limited so strongly suggest arriving at 2:30.
results.name: The Amazing Nina Simone - FREE Film Screening Sat Mar 5

results.description:
Rated PG   93 minutes  view trailer

The Good Dinosaur (2015)

March 4, 2016 at 8:00 pm in 26-100

March 5, 2016 at 4:00 pm in 10-250

</a> FREE admission, sponsored by the <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/funny">de Florez Fund for Humor

In this enchanting computer-animated fantasy, set in a world where the dinosaurs never went extinct, an amiable young Apatosaurus named Arlo (voiced by Raymond Ochoa) loses his father in a storm and is swept away by a vicious river current, stranding him in a frightening new place far from his home. He soon embarks on a journey to reunite with his family, and befriends a prehistoric human child known as Spot (Jack Bright) along the way. Peter Sohn directed this heartwarming Pixar adventure, with Jeffrey Wright, Frances McDormand, Anna Paquin, and Sam Elliott also contributing voice work. [www.allmovie.com] 

"The Good Dinosaur" has an original concept, disarming emotional heft and features the most impressive visuals in animated cinema to date. 
      -- Peter Hartlaub, San Francisco Chronicle. Read this review.

Please note that this event is for Saturday's 4pm showing. There is also a free showing tonight (Friday) with free popcorn in room26-100.

This event is cross-posted to FACT-Boston, Social Fun, The Middle, and BargainDating.

results.name: Free Movie Screening of "The Good Dinosaur" at MIT (room 10-250)

results.description:
We traditionally have a large social meetup twice each month. This gives everyone an opportunity to come and make new friends, practice their Japanese or English, and spend time with a bunch of interesting people from around the Boston area and overseas.  This meetup may be cancelled if there are very few RSVPs.

Close to Boylston on the Green Line, or Chinatown on the Orange Line.
Also a short walk from Park Street or Downtown Crossing. 

• From Boylston Station, go south on Tremont Street (away from Boston Common),  then take a right onto Stuart Street.  The food court will be on your right; you enter the building right by the Dunkin Donuts.

• From Chinatown Station, go west on Boylston Street (toward Boston Common), then take a left onto Tremont Street. Turn right onto Stuart Street. The food court will be on your right; you enter the building right by the Dunkin Donuts.

There is a map of the area below. If you have trouble finding us, please feel free to call or text me at[masked]-2923.  Also you can call or text if you come after we have left for Chinatown, although then there is a greater chance I will miss the call.

Come on by, relax, practice in either language of your choice, and enjoy being part of our growing community!

The Meetup does not end at 6 - instead, some time around there, we usually go out to Chinatown for dinner afterwards to eat family style - anyone who wants to come is welcome. The cost is usually around $12-20/person (not including any drinks for which people pay their own way).  We are open to restaurant suggestions.  However, I am not willing to get into dividing up large numbers of orders on one giant check, which is why we generally go to Chinatown and split everything down the middle.  If you don't want to eat at all, you can come and just enjoy the company for free.  

Please BRING CASH if you can and want to go to dinner - many of the restaurants limit cards to two per table, so if a lot of people have no cash it can be a problem.

Stuart Street view

results.description:
Celebrate this leap year by traveling with us through time. We will be marathon the anime series Steins;Gate.

Synopsis 


"The self-proclaimed mad scientist Rintarou Okabe rents out a room in a rickety old building in Akihabara, where he indulges himself in his hobby of inventing prospective 'future gadgets' with fellow lab members: Mayuri Shiina, his air-headed childhood friend, and Hashida Itaru, a perverted hacker nicknamed "Daru." The three pass the time by tinkering with their most promising contraption yet, a machine dubbed the "Phone Microwave," which performs the strange function of morphing bananas into piles of green gel.

Though miraculous in itself, the phenomenon doesn't provide anything concrete in Okabe's search for a scientific breakthrough; that is, until the lab members are spurred into action by a string of mysterious happenings before stumbling upon an unexpected success—the Phone Microwave can send emails to the past, altering the flow of history.

Adapted from the critically acclaimed visual novel by 5pb. and Nitroplus, Steins;Gate takes Okabe through the depths of scientific theory and practicality. Forced across the diverging threads of past and present, Okabe must shoulder the burdens that come with holding the key to the realm of time."

----------------------------------------------------

Between socializing, snacking, and discussing the time travel theory, we won't make it through the whole series in one night... But we will get as many episodes in as possible.

Food and Drinks: Not that I need to say this, but we need to respect the venue. Please clean up after yourselves and don't leave a mess. That being said, feel free to bring any type of food, snack, or beverage to share. Alcohol is NOT permitted at this venue. 

Location note: the address is 19 Myrtle St, Boston MA 02114

Transportation and Parking: there is no parking at this location. The nearest T stop is park street or Charles mgh. Please plan accordingly. :)

Look forward to seeing you there.

results.description:
I'm excited for my new place! The basement is set up for jamming, so I hope to host about 2 sessions a week. This is the first one. I'll be sure to prepare some food and drinks.

I have everything necessary (drums, amps, keys, guitars, bass), but you can bring whatever you want. I don't have many effects. I need to restring my second guitar... but everyone brings their own guitars and effects anyway.

I typically play simple repetitive patterns using a few tones. I usually stick to pentatonic scales or to a single key for a while. I find this helps everyone stick together. I will also usually play in 4/4 time (this seems to be everyone's default), but I'm very interested in other meters.

I also record the sessions and send them to whomever is interested. If you'd rather the session NOT be recorded, let me know.

Let me know if you have any questions.

results.description:
Be there or be square! 

Not too swanky. Just... HARVARD SQUARE! 

Don't get territorial about seats we have a Mix and Mingle environment thanks to John Harvard's. We're here to meet as many peeps as possible, right?

It's time for another Happy Hour and this time we're back in Cambridge!

https://www.johnharvards.com/locations/cambridge-ma/
John Harvard's Brew House has it's own brewery so unique, beer samplers ("flights") are recommended, yu get extra beer that way, 6 samples of 4 oz each why so many?  Cuz there is always one you just don't like. Or else, ask at the bar to taste something free.

This is a rolling come and go as you can event. Some folks come just for a drink, others hang out and chat for a few hours. There's good food here too. The event typically winds up around 8pm, although some members organize and grab some dinner after.

The wait staff is extraordinary, even under pressure they are charming & patient; please bring cash and tip well pay as you go! (Or else leave your credit card with the waiter).

Seating gets dicey if you get there late.

results.description:
MEDIUM COOL TICKETS

In Tribute to Haskell Wexler!Screens in place of MATEWAN. Double Feature with CLOSE ENCOUNTERS OF THE THIRD KIND

(1969) dir Haskell Wexler w/Robert Forster, Verna Bloom, Peter Bonerz, Marianna Hill [111 min; Digital]


The apotheosis of Wexler’s career, MEDIUM COOL combines social commentary and documentary style with the taught character study of a television cameraman (Forster) shooting at the 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago.

“With its mix of fictional storytelling and documentary technique, [MEDIUM COOL] is a visceral cinematic snapshot of the era, climaxing with an extended sequence shot right in the middle of the riots surrounding the Convention. An inventive commentary on the pleasures and dangers of wielding a camera, Medium Cool is as prescient a political film as Hollywood has ever produced.” – The Criterion Collection

ROTTEN TOMATOES:  95%

undefined

CLOSE ENCOUNTERS AT  8:15* PM

Join us for a film that 'is as prescient a political film as Hollywood has ever produced'.  I've never seen, or heard of this film, and it is only showing due to the cancellation of MATEWAN, which is definitively worth seeing in June.

This film is what I truly value about this group.  A cinematic experiences that is 'as amazing as I thought it was?' which can only be validated by a shared experience.

After, we can either go for dinner and discussion, or stay for CLOSE ENCOUNTERS, which contains its own amazingness, and fodder for historic late night discussion.

See you at a movie you and I may have never heard of, during a historic election year,

John
results.how_to_find_us: We'll Meetup after close of credits inside the Brattle in the front row of the stage.  John will be holding an authentic, handmade MEETUP sign.  We can look for somewhere for dinner and discussion, or stay for CLOSE ENCOUNTERS.
results.name: MEDIUM COOL

results.description:
My name is Madison White, Kelle has graciously allowed me to share this event with you lovely Goddesses.

I am a former burlesque performer of 6 years based out of Boston, I'm also a Registered Nurse, Jikiden Reiki Practicioner and soon to be Life Activation Practicioner and Meditation Teacher. I am passionated about divine feminine empowerment and teaching women tools to develop and own their sacred sensual power. A few years ago I developed a meditation lovingly entitled "Vajoga". It is with much joy that I am pleased to offer this 'twerkshop' as a way to boost our connection with our sacred sensuality and learn how to express it through movement. During these three classes, through meditation, introspection, group activities, and intuitive movement we will explore the sacred temple of our bodies and strengthen our self confidence and sensuality.

There are about five spots left in the class. They are three consecutive Saturdays in March 5th, 12th and 19th from 6-8pm at Green Street Studios (studio #3) 185 Green St. in Central Square, Cambridge. Classes are $20 in advance, $25 at the door (cash only) or $50 for all 3 classes in advance. I'm so honored to be sharing this sacred expression with you, Goddesses.

For more information or to register please email me / send payment via PayPal at [masked] I would be ecstatic to meet and join you in dance. Much love and blessings
Madison White
results.name: Church of Twerk - a 'twerkshop' presented by Madison White

results.description:
This looks interesting.  Tina Fey is the star, but basically, I will see any movie that has Martin Freeman as part of the cast. 


Showtime is  7:15.  I will probably get to the theater about an hour beforehand, the theater will let us start going upstairs around 6:30.  We will gather at the tables at the top of the escalators near the big windows and head in for seats at 6:45.

In general, I arrive at the theater an hour before the show to start gathering people, and we head in for seats about 30 minutes before the show, so we can sit together. This also allows us to take turns getting snacks, etc., before the previews start.  It also allows for any unexpected, last minute changes at the theater.  Although fairly infrequent, having wiggle room to exchange tickets, etc. is VERY helpful.

Please note, everyone is responsible for buying their own tickets.  And while it is possible to buy your ticket at the door, shows often sell out. I strongly advise you to buy your tickets in advance.  I will announce when tickets go on sale on Fandango. Please do NOT buy tickets until I have finalized the time.

If you miss the group ahead of time, come find us after. We gather in the hallway outside of the theater we just saw the movie in, to discuss the film a bit, allow for restroom breaks and to get a head count of all those who would like to go out after for drinks and munchies.

$$$$Managing the after event is much easier if everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead if you want to go out with the group after.  We will be splitting one bill for the group. No separate checks.$$$

One more thing, please keep your rsvp's up to date so I can plan the after event and know who to look for.  Thanks!

Movie Details:

Release date: March 4, 2016

Studio: Paramount Pictures

Directors: Glenn Ficarra, John Requa

MPAA Rating: N/A

Screenwriter: Robert Carlock

Starring: Tina Fey, Margot Robbie, Martin Freeman, Alfred Molina, Billy Bob Thornton

Genre: Drama, Comedy, Biography

Official website: WhiskeyTangoFoxtrotthemovie.com| Facebook| Twitter| Instagram

Plot Summary:

An adaptation of journalist Kim Barker’s wartime memoir, "The Taliban Shuffle." The story recounts Barker’s experiences covering conflicts in Afghanistan and Pakistan. It's said to be a dark comedy dealing with Barker's fish-out-of-water experience and the challenges of being a woman in wartime Afghanistan and Pakistan.
results.name: Whiskey Tango Foxtrot (7:15PM Show)

results.description:
Indulge yourself in healing sounds and journey in a safe and sacred space. Allow the sounds, frequencies, vibrations and energy move through you; melting away the stress. Help yourself rebalance, and relax. Tibetan bowls, gongs, chanting, mantras, native drum and other sacred sound instruments. Let the sound take you on an inner journey and you lay in stillness and mindfulness. 


Energetic contribution of 30$.


Please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket to ensure your comfort. 

Private sessions and instruction available by appointment.

Many blessings, 

Sarah -  Unega Awia (White Deer Song) 


A little about myself and my work through the voice of my clients:

Sarah Surrenders- White Deer Song- Is an Intuitive Healer who uses Sound as her main medium for healing. She is a Shamanic Practicioner, Legally Certified Spiritual Healer, Reiki Certified And Professionally Certified Sound Healer. Sarah leads retreats, workshops, Sound Healing classes, group sessions and offers private healings. Her focus is to help people come into their power, overcome challenges, releasing past emotional traumas, stress and anxiety reduction as well as soothing physical pain. Sarah has had beautiful responses to working on issues surrounding infertility, hormonal imbalance, anxiety, grief, depression and emotional traumas. Sarah travels extensively to pursue her studies, share the magic of sound as a healing tool and to recharge and continue her spiritual nomadic path in service and dedication.

Reviews:


1.Sarah is absolutely amazing, she helped me deal with and move on from issues that had been dormant for many years. The outcome of my sessions was extremely positive and I am forever grateful that Sarah was able to guide me through my healing process with her beautiful sounds! If I could give a 10 star rating, I would. Thank you Sarah!!!! 2. Two years ago I met Sara through a mutual friend at a time I needed healing the most. During her group sessions, she taught us to meditate and calm our thoughts while she played her Himalayan bowls, tuning forks and many other shamanic healing techniques. With her guidance I found an inner calmness and some clarity. After a few sessions I decided I would go deeper into myself and asked for Sara to guide me in private sessions. What happened in these sessions has changed me and given me strength to believe and listen to my inner self all while healing some core issues I haven't dealt with, stemming from as far back as my childhood!  Sara you are an angel among angels. I am grateful. Thank you

 2. It's hard to find a true healer that is meant to help others and trust someone to heal you, but since the first practice with Sarah I felt so connected and truly amazed by results. So strong, devoted and passionate, ready to give whatever it takes to help. Thank you so much for wonderful experiences, visions, expansion and healing.. !

3. It's been over a year now and Sarah continues to help me and my family clear our paths and the results have been incredible - and now we are doing this long distance! What a blessing it has been to find this beautiful teacher and guide on our journey. When in the presence of someone whose work is their life's purpose, it can be felt and in Sarah's case, heard! Beautiful sounds creating beautiful results! Feeling lighter and more peaceful. Thank you so much. xo

4. Peace - love - calmness within you it's absolutely amazing; can't wait to see you Sarah at your next session!!

5. Wow. Get a sound healing from Sarah as soon as possible. It is really a life changing experience. We get so caught up in the world around us that we end up missing the world inside us. My experience with Sarah helped me get back in touch with my inner-world. What Sarah offers through her intuitive gifts, shamanic training, singing bowls and tuning forks is absolutely transformative. She is able to help you work through mental, emotional and physical blockages through the power of sound. I can't recommend Sarah more highly because she is the best at what she does. I've been practicing sound healing for years and Sarah is the most remarkable sound healer and teacher I've ever met. She does not just play the bowls. She invites them. Each time, depending on who she is healing, the bowls sound a different story and her intuitive power discovers what the story is and how it wants to play out. There are very few people that have this ability but what makes Sarah even more special is that she has the boundless compassion to heal with elegance and grace. I hope as many people support Sarah as possible as she is doing such an important service for all beings. She also does distant healings which are extremely effective. So, please, follow Sarah, receive a healing and be blessed in the source of beauty through which Sarah breathes, expands and heals.

results.description:
As the second largest wine producing state in the US, Washington offers a wide range of varietals and styles, which should make for a fun and interesting blind tasting. Pretty much any style you can think of - from sparkling to still, dry to dessert, made from over 30 grape varieties, can be found in Washington.


There are 13 AVAs (American Viticultural Areas) in the state, the largest being the Columbia, Yakima, and Walla Walla Valleys. The remaining smaller AVAs, such as Red Mountain, Horsehead Hills and Puget Sound, exist within these larger areas.  The most common varieties from Washington are Riesling, Chardonnay, Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Syrah. But no need to limit yourself to these varietals - there are plenty of others to choose from!


Washington wines are about 50% red and 50% white, so let's try to have a similar breakdown at our tasting. (We can use the "Comments" section to track what everyone is bringing after they RSVP.) I'll provide a main course, but please plan to bring an appetizer or dessert to share, plus $10 to help cover the cost of the room. And of course, you'll need a bottle of wine ($15+) and 4 glasses for the tasting.

Note:  We'll have the tasting at the "great room" at my apartment complex in Arlington, which is a shared space for the building. The room has a kitchenette, pool table and large TV, but the main thing is that it gives us plenty of space for everyone to have a comfortable seat and still be able to move around and mingle. I will reserve the space so we'll have it to ourselves, but there is a charge for this, so I'm asking everyone to chip in.
results.name: Wines from Washington State

20 Free Tickets for a “Night Out at the Symphony”

Ellen C has offered to provide a meeting spot for the group.......please make it as simple for her to run as possible.....ie only sign up if you can make it, don't bombard with questions you can answer by reading the post.  Thank you and have a great time!

The Melrose Symphony has made a limited number of free tickets available for its next concert on Saturday, March 5, 2016, at 8 pm. The first 20 people to use the discount code “northshoreladies” will receive free tickets.

Please only reserve a ticket if you can make it, as we really want them to continue to extend their offers to us:)

CLICK HERE FOR TICKETS:  http://www.melrosesymphony.org/marchmasterworks/

Concert Details

Saturday, March 5, 2016, 8 pm, pre-concert talk is free and starts at 7:15 pm (doors open at 7 pm)

Memorial Hall, 590 Main Street, Melrose, MA 02176

Seating is General Admission

Bobby C’s Ristorante provides light snacks (cheese plates, dessert plates) and beverages (beer, wine, sodas). Melrose has a variety of fantastic restaurants within walking distance from the concert venue.

Concert Program

The Melrose Symphony will perform works by two epic composers, Ludwig van Beethoven and film composer Miklós Rózsa. Conductor Yoichi Udagawa will educate audiences from the stage about the genius of these composers and their masterworks. You will hear three phenomenal works:

Rózsa - Parade of the Charioteers from "Ben Hur"

Rózsa - Sinfonia Concertante, Op. 29
with Boston Symphony musicians, Lucia Lin, violin & Owen Young, cello

Beethoven - Symphony No. 5

The concert highlights powerfully emotional and passionate music from film composer Miklós Rózsa, opening with his “Parade of the Charioteers” from the 1959 movie Ben Hur. Rózsa won three Oscars and composed nearly 100 film scores including Ben Hur, Spellbound, The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes, and Double Indemnity.


In addition to film scores, Rózsa also composed traditional concert music such as his Sinfonia Concertante written for violin and cello soloists with orchestra. The MSO is excited to welcome back acclaimed Boston Symphony musicians violinist Lucia Lin and cellist Owen Young to perform this exciting and evocative work.


Closing the concert is perhaps the most recognizable piece in all symphonic literature with its famous  four-note introduction: Beethoven’s monumental “5th Symphony.

results.description:
By Jürgen Lobert


This is part of our indoor winter program and the third and last part of the Introduction to night photography series, which focuses on light painting.


This is an advanced lecture about adding artificial light to night photos through a number of techniques, about 90 minutes long. It is strongly recommended that you attend the "Introduction to night photography" lecture or have at least some experience with light painting.


There are three different activities, collectively often referred to as "light painting".  I like to differentiate the following:

• Light painting: you don't see the actual light source. Think of it as using a paint brush of light to illuminate existing surfaces. You emphasize the objects.

• Light drawing: this is where you point the light at the camera and draw up shapes and figures. You create new objects, background may be secondary or complementary.

• Light writing: the same as drawing, except that you write actual words or do light calligraphy. Very specialized and quite difficult to do well, we will not go much into this. You create messages, the background becomes secondary.

Here is a rough outline of what will be covered:

• Basic settings: what's different from regular NPy?

  - adding light to fill in dark shadows (equalize)

  - adding light as a major (and visible) component (emphasize)

• Light sources for light painting:

  - flashlights: LED, incandescent, light colors

  - flashes

  - light gadgets: trip to the toy store, anyone?

• Light modifiers: reflectors, snoots, baffles, gel filters and paint brushes

• What makes an object look interesting? Hint: it's shadows!

• The basic concepts:

• How to • Light Painting: how to convert a flashlight into a paint brush

• Light Drawing: unleash your arteestic side

• Light Writing: calligraphy, anyone?

• The three secrets to becoming a master in this.
results.name: Lecture: Introduction to Light Painting

results.description:
Hi all. I am new to this meetup group. I work with Radius Ensemble, a Boston-based chamber music ensemble of winds, strings, and piano. The ensemble's thoughtfully curated programs balance old and new, with repertoire ranging from beloved masterworks to riveting new music. 

Radius' next performance is this Saturday at 8pm in Cambridge (details below). 

I know this is last-minute, but if anyone is interested in attending and meeting up afterwards, there is an informal reception following each performance on site where you can talk to other attendees and the musicians. 

This is not a free event and requires a ticket, but for those that would like to attend, we can offer 25% off general admission tickets. Tickets are $12-24 when purchased online at http://radiusensemble.org/concert3. Tickets are also available at the door with a nominal surcharge. Discount code: MEETUP326


Saturday night's performance will be special, as we are bringing together music, an interactive technology element, and audience participation with the world premiere of Eun Young Lee's *12*. The world premiere of *12* for the entire ensemble, will be accompanied by 12 smartphone players drawn from the audience, who will trigger 40+ distinctive pre-recorded percussion sounds. Inspired by the Zodiac, *12* is a collaboration between Eun Young Lee, the computer scientist and musician Eran Egozy (founder of Harmonix, creators of Guitar Hero and Rock Band and now Professor in Music Technology at MIT) and visual artist Jeff Hesser (digital artist at Harmonix).

Full Program:
POULENC – Sextet for piano and winds
LEE, EUN YOUNG – *12* for ensemble, with audience (WORLD PREMIERE)
Plus a quartet for flute and strings by the winner of the fourth annual Pappalardo Composition Competition
results.name: Radius Ensemble Performance with World Premiere of *12*

results.description:
The Back Bay Chorale presents two settings of the great Latin hymn, bridged by Mozart’s Symphony 39 in E-flat major —a musical connection to the tension and dolor of the Stabat Mater theme.

This is elegant choral music and perfect for the season.  Be moved by the stunning voice of soloist and Boston's own, Jacquelyn Stucker, Soprano, with the support of the wonderful Back Bay Chorale Orchestra - and featuring the orchestra for Mozart's Symphony 39 in E-flat.  

"As the Easter season approaches, the “Stabat Mater” stands as a musical expression of the overwhelming grief of a mother at the death of her child. It is considered one of the greatest Latin hymns, packed with vivid descriptions and exquisitely phrased form."

The Chorale presents two settings of this hymn, bridged by Mozart’s Symphony 39 in E-flat major—a musical connection to the tension and dolor of the Stabat Mater theme."

As a POSSIBLE meetup, please consider buying a ticket in Mezzanine F, $32.00 (student) to $37.00 (regular) ("blue" seats) or of course sit where you like. I'm unable to be host. This meetup will work if you purchase a ticket in this section, AND WEAR ANYTHING RED (bright if you have it! scarf, tie, hat) As a bonus, please comment if you'd like to gather before or after event. Host (TBD) can coordinate.

TICKETS and INFO:   http://bbcboston.org/performances/verdi-mozart-poulenc/   (Use discount code "SMITH" to save a few bucks...)

Lastly, here's a great translation of the text.  http://www.preces-latinae.org/thesaurus/BVM/SMDolorosa.html

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked] 


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to one 4,000 footer in New Hampshire - Owl's Head. We will use Lincoln Woods Trail, the Black Pond Bushwhack, Lincoln Brook Trail, the Brutus Bushwhack, and the Owl's Head Spur Trail to reach the summit before turning around and retracing our steps to get back to our cars.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 10 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 16 miles and climb about 3,400 feet. It should take an average hiker about 10 hours to complete. This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/43-Owls-Head-4025

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.1441&lon=-71.6048#.VpcvHTblweI


=== What to Bring ===


Don't wear ANY cotton - this includes your socks and underwear. You will need winter hiking boots - if you wear them in the summer they aren't designed for winter use (e.g. insulation). You will need mountaineering snow shoes. Not all snowshoes are the same - some are designed for steep terrain with potentially deep snow while others aren't. These are the acceptable brands and models:

• Tubbs Flex ALP, Flex VRT, Flex TRK, or Mountaineers.

• MSR Lightening, Revo, or Evo. 

• TSL Symbioz Elite or Expert. 

• Atlas Aspect, Endeavor, or Series 10/11/12.

You will also need traction - while you can bring mountaineering crampons if you want I think all you will need is either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike:


• </a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Lincoln Woods Visitors Center which is located on the north side of Route 112 east of Lincoln, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 135 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 10 minutes to drive there. Since this is where we will end the day we will leave a few cars there and drive to the starting spot.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

• </a><a href="https://goo.gl/maps/fnmNxuEiKxm">https://goo.gl/maps/fnmNxuEiKxm

</a>

<a href="https://goo.gl/maps/NhpBuQBan5R2">

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
The 5Rhythms and Conscious Relating

 The dancing deep workshop  is an extreme invitation for you to come as you are. Come with broken or joyous hearts, come with bum knees or off the ground ecstatic exuberance. All levels of movement experience welcome. When we are true in our relating, we create a community that thrives  and flourishes.

We are all beginners each time we gather.

Teens and Adults welcome.

The 5 Rhythms are states of  being that invite us to find the rhythm we were born with, find the rhythm we grew up with, find the rhythm we have a hard time with and find the rhythm that we feel when we move to our edges.

 Flowing ( Letting in)

Staccato ( Letting out) 

Chaos ( Letting go)

 Lyrical ( Letting go of letting go)

 Stillness ( Let it be)

 The 5 Rhythms movement practice is map which guides us into the  gateways of the knowledge and sacred wisdom of the body. How do we consciously or unconsciously  ask for what we want when we are  alone, with someone, with others? As we move back into the body through movement and stay present while  we consciously relate, we once again to deeply trust in ourselves.

 Awareness through movement and conscious relating  assists us in finding an easy flow in our body and in our life.  This practice focuses on relationship to self and others, freedom,  fun, a willingness to experience your yes and no, your dancing feet and your connection to spirit. Your spirit.

Breathe deeper and become more alive by just being you.

Please wear and bring  layers of comfortable clothes to move in

 Soft soled shoes or non slip socks  are best to move in  

The café may or may not be open on Sunday, so bring a snack if you like.

For  Ticket Registration : www.margauxskalecki.com  and see the PAYPAL tab

results.description:
Greater Boston Oasis meets every week for engaging speakers, live musicians, and the opportunity to connect with the community. Details of the speakers, musical guests, etc. will be posted in the individual meetups as they are confirmed.

Doors for the event open at 10:00 AM for coffee and conversation, with the program starting at 10:30. We hope to see you there!

=========================================

Oasis calls itself a community based on shared values. We talk all the time about how the things we discuss in our Sunday Gatherings tie back to the Oasis core values. But how do we, the members of the Oasis community, bring those values into our daily lives. How does "People are more important than beliefs" change how you interact with others? How does "Meaning comes from making a difference" affect your decision-making?

This week, we'll dedicate the "main talk" portion of our Sunday Gathering to a discussion of the Oasis core values, how different members of the community interpret them, what we find challenging in them, and how they impact us when it's not Sunday morning. All are welcome to join the discussion!

=========================================

Oasis meets in the Teen Center at the YMCA. To find the room, enter through the lower entrance (on Dartmouth Street, by the swimming pool), and follow Oasis signs from the front lobby to the Teen Center on the second floor. (Note: the stairwell to the Teen Center is NOT the stairwell in the front lobby. That is Stairwell A. The Teen Center is located at Stairwell B, next to the Yoga Studio. Oasis volunteers will be available to help provide assistance, and signage will be posted.


=========================================


Greater Boston Oasis is a secular community dedicated to providing for the human need for social and intellectual community, for those people who may not want or be able to have those needs met in a church or other faith-based community. 

Our Core Values are:


People are more important than beliefs

Reality is known through reason

Meaning comes from making a difference

Human hands solve human problems

Be accepting, and be accepted


Atheist or agnostic, freethinker or skeptic, deist or theist, all those with whom those values resonate are welcome to celebrate the human experience.
results.how_to_find_us: Follow signs from the entrance to the Teen Center room. Use the Dartmouth Street entrance, and head to Stairwell B. Teen Center is on the 2nd floor.
results.name: Sunday Gathering: Oasis Values in Action

results.description:
TIME CHANGE:  If you have already registered, please call the number below to change your reservation time.

**Participants must call to register and pay in advance:  [masked]-9264.  Specify the 10:30 tour.**

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

~Optional food/lunch afterwards~

Weekend Maple Sugaring Tours

Spring celebrations begin early at the sanctuary with the age-old tradition of maple sugaring. The warm days of late winter awaken the flow of sap in the maples, causing buds to swell and resulting in sweet-smelling, billowing clouds of steam rising from the sugarhouse.

On our naturalist-guided tours, learn how to identify a sugar maple, observe tapping and sap collection methods, watch the sap being boiled down in the sugarhouse, and get a sweet taste of the final product. Afterwards, warm up by the woodstove in the Barn, where hot beverages, hot dogs cooked in maple sap, and delicious soups and desserts made by our volunteers are available for purchase.

Visit our gift shop to browse a selection of maple products, and be sure to bring home a bottle of our own freshly-made maple syrup.

Tours last about an hour and run in all weather. Dress warmly and wear warm waterproof boots because the walk is entirely outdoors.

Adults

$9 member of MA Audubon Society
$10 nonmember of MA Audubon Society

ADVANCED REGISTRATION & PAYMENT IS REQUIRED.  [masked])

results.description:
Back to WSF, one of the many hidden gems of the Pioneer Valley!


We’ll hike an approximate 8-9+ mile loop on a combination of fire/woods roads with a few rocky trails mixed in for an overall elevation gain of about 1500’+.


From the Lookouts we’ll get a view of the Berkshires to the south and west.  And, assuming they'll welcome us, we'll visit the Porcupine Ledges.

Consider this to be a Easy/Moderate hike with a few ascents that may be difficult for inexperienced hikers.  There will be three stretches where we'll have an elevation gain of 300'-400' in less than one-half mile+.   Difficulty ratings are based on elevation gain.  Please factor in your own ability and willingness to hike 8-9 miles on a cold day.  Check out Difficulty Ratings at:

http://hikenewengland.com/LegendRating.html

Expect the duration of the hike to be up to five hours plus a four hour round-trip from eastern MA.  Plan your day accordingly.

Carpooling is welcome.  If you would like to carpool you're welcome to post that request in the *Comments* section of the event's page.  But please respond to those posts via *Meetup Messenger*.  You do that by clicking on a member's profile, then clicking on *message*..

Cell Phones and Electronic Devices:  I ask that while on the BSOT events that I host you limit your use of electronic devices to the following activities:

Map My Hike or other Hiking Apps

Location Services

Cameras

Weather Apps

Of the many pleasant features of being out and about is that we all get away from the constant distractions of cell phones and electronics.  I ask that while on the events I host you:

Do not use your phone (of course! I make exceptions for emergencies and calling a taxi/Uber if you can't make it back on foot!)

Do not listen to the radio.

Do not play music.

Thank you in advance for respecting this request.


http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-central/wendell-state-forest.html

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metacomet-Monadnock_Trail

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wendell,_Massachusetts

<a>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_Valley</a>;

And NO, this trek is not just a lame excuse to eat at The Old Mill. 


http://www.1761oldmill.com/

Directions:

From The East/Northeast/Southeast

Assuming that everyone will be coming up Route 2 from the east:

After Exit 14 in Orange:  (W. River Street/Orange/Lake Mattawa) continue on Rt 2 for a little over a mile. 

 You’ll cross the bridge over the Millers River.  Note the Entering Orange sign on your left, followed soon by an Entering Erving sign.

Right at the Entering Erving sign put on your blinker and start to slow down as you’ll be taking the next left, Rt 2A East.  Be careful here as this is a tricky left to take as you’ll be crossing the oncoming traffic. 

Take the left, then another left at the end of the ramp.  You’re now heading east on 2A toward Orange.  Proceed for about 0.5 miles and take the right onto Wendell Depot Road.  There’s a green sign with white lettering and arrow that reads Wendell Center.  You’ll soon go over the Millers River, under RT 2, and cross railroad tracks.

Drive about 4.5 miles to Wendell Center.  Don’t expect a village, all you get is a library on the right and a church/meeting house on the left.  (If you make as far as the little market and PO you’ve gone too far).  At Wendell Center take a right onto Montague Road (there’s a brown DCR sign here for Wendell State Forest). Proceed on Montague Road for about 3.5 miles, Wendell State Forest Headquarters is right there on the right. Brown maintenance buildings, trucks in the parking lot, etc.  Pull in.  You made it!

For those with GPS:

Please note that the destination is 392 Montague Road, Wendell, MA.  Some sources have the address as Millers Falls, MA.  Use Wendell. There are two main roads in Wendell (population 848).  One road goes north/south, the other east/west.  WSF is easy to find.  Print out these directions and bring them with you.

I recently tested the route using IPhone’s Siri, AT&T is my provider.  It brought me right to the parking lot without a hitch.  I don’t know if those using Verizon, Sprint, or others will have coverage as the region is somewhat off the grid.


<a></a> The Fine Print:

Duration: Approximately 5 hours. However, any time estimate given by an Event Organizer is just that. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the group itself. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time. There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgment. Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" or about whom we have received complaints from fellow hikers will not be accepted.

If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can adhere to these basic prerequisites. Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up.

This hike is rated easy/moderate.  You should be able to stay with the group going at a pace of 2+ mph. This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the leader, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy snow or extreme cold weather cancels. Bring water, hiking boots (not sneakers), bug spray and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

NO DOGS and NO GUESTS are allowed on this hike. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.Please remember that your Event Organizers are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. (woof!) If you need everything to run perfectly this hike is not for you.

By clicking the "Yes" option on the RSVP link you are agreeing to the Liability Waiver as stated below: Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. results.description:
Greetings!

I have a membership to Dedham Health Athletic Club.  So, if you're interested, I can get you in for some Winter Tennis.

Guests will have to pay $20 guest fee plus her/his share of court fees.

If we play on the weekends between 6a-5p, it's $26/hr (split by # of players, max 4 per court of course).  If we play between 5p-10p, it's $22/hr.

Please Note:  There is a 48 Hour Cancellation Policy for these courts.  So, we have to confirm that we will play or take our chances on reserving a court the day of.

Please RSVP if you're interested.  Right now it's open for 4 people.  If those fill up and 4 more join the waitlist, then I'll open it up to 8 people and so on.  I'll send a final note 4 days before so that we can make a decision prior to cancellation. 

The more folks who express some interest, the more we can make helpful groupings based on skill level.  It's presumed to be mixed doubles but that can be discussed.  We can also rotate tennis clubs if anyone wants to host.

Hope there's some interest as I have a brand new racquet that I'd love to put to more use!

(Note anyone can set up a meetup in this meetup group now.  If you'd like to play at a different time or with certain skillset, feel free to list it.  Just be sure you have all of your details lined up such as Type of player, Where, When, How Much, How Many, etc.)

Chris J.

results.description:
This is a hot new pair on the literary scene: Albert Camu's "The Stranger", together with the modern Algerian response: Daoud's "The Meursault Investigation." Daoud's narrative Point of View is the brother of the murdered Algerian in The Stranger. The book takes off from The Stranger (an extension,  a critique, a historical and a philosophical re-examination of French Colonialism, both positive and negative). Both books are translated from French. 


Because they are both short, we would like to read both and we look forward to you joining the lively discussion to come.


Here is one of many news item on this pair. http://www.npr.org/2015/08/21/432618805/novelist-kamel-daoud-finding-dignity-in-the-absurd
results.name: March: Kamel Daoud's The Meursault Investigation AND Camus's The Stranger

results.description:
Hi Urban Sketchers,

Let's head to the Harvard Museum of Natural History to sketch! 

Plan is to meet in lobby of museum at 11:15am, start sketching at 11:30, then meet back in lobby to share our work at 1:30pm.

Don't forget your Massachusetts ID so you can get in for FREE!

The Harvard Museum of Natural History was created in 1998 as the “public face” of three research museums — the Museum of Comparative Zoology, the Harvard Mineralogical and Geological Museum, and the Harvard University Herbaria (I did not know this was a word).

 It hosts a variety of natural world exhibitions, including a large glass flower collection. The museum is on the Harvard University campus and is the school's most visited attraction. 

The details for this event: The museum entrance is free before 12:00PM for all Massachusetts residents with proof of residency so bring your state ID (or rental agreement?). Otherwise the museum is $10 for students and $12 for adults. If you have a Harvard ID, are a Harvard Museums member, a teacher, an ASTC passport program member, or apart of active duty military, the entrance is also free. 

Drawing is encouraged in the galleries, but the use of clay, paints, pastels, and chalk is NOT permitted. So bring your pens, pencils and colored pencils! I think that about covers it, hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the lobby of the museum at 11:15am and be sure to get your free admission ticket first!
results.name: Let's Sketch! The Harvard Museum of Natural History
