results.description:
Rowan Morrigan spent 22 years in LA as an editor and director. After returning to New England a few years ago, he was in search of an ideal film to produce that might have sequel possibilities, in addition to offering a first great feature. Enter novelist Inanna Arthen and her book series based on vampires of New England. Next Monday they are presenting the screenplay Mortal Touch (based on the novel of the same name), as a collaboration. Inanna is the screenwriter and Rowan has been the creative producer on this project.

Log Line:
A lonely vampire stops running from his past when he unites with a reclusive psychic, bullied teenager and desperate woman to defeat a common enemy.

Writer Bio:
Inanna Arthen/Vyrdolak (http://inannaarthen.com) is an artist, actor, freelance book designer and author of The Vampires of New England Series (http://vampiresofnewengland.com): Mortal Touch (2007), The Longer The Fall (2010), and All The Shadows of The Rainbow (2013). Book 4 is currently in progress. Inanna is a lifelong scholar of vampire folklore, fiction and media who created the non-fiction vampire studies website By Light Unseen (http://bylightunseen.net) in 1997. Since 2007 she has run By Light Unseen Media (http://bylightunseenmedia.com), an independent press dedicated to publishing vampire fiction and nonfiction by U.S. and Canadian authors.

Mortal Touch (the novel) has sold some 5,000 copies, has netted its author around $25,000 to date and is still By Light Unseen Media's best selling title. It has now been adapted into Mortal Touch (the screenplay).

Producer Bio:
Rowan Morrigan (http://rowan.us/) has been in the entertainment industry for 22 years in Los Angeles before returning to Massachusetts in 2013 to pursue a career as a creative producer in feature film. Rowan has worked as a film editor and director on a variety of indy projects. He has completed two programs in film studies at UCLA. He has been a member of Harvard Square Script Writers for about 25 years and is a producer on two current films: a short titled Our Father and a feature film titled Last Call at Murray’s. He recently wrote an article for the HSSW website: Unveiling the Mysteries of Attending Cannes for the First Time.

Dues, as always is $15.00 to cover rent and admin.
results.name: Get Inside the World of Vampirism with the Screenplay Mortal Touch

results.description:
Notice the change of day for this particular event: Monday.  We are going to try to do some of the Tuesdays at Adam's house (with a Monday event at my house this same week).  Hopefully we get more gaming options and more people can participate in at least one of the events.


===========


Contact me [Jose (click the link, then click "Message")] for the address.

General board gaming. We have a good library of widely played board games, and people normally bring many more of them. We regularly run three to five tables of board games - this provides enough variety.  It is normal for people to get two or three games a session.  The game night format was inspired by Unity Games and the event is very casual and structureless.  If you have gone to one of the meetup's quarterly events you will know.

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played?
A.  Any type of board game.  Browse through the most popular games at http://boardgamegeek.com/ and that should give you an idea.

Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm?
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  Should I bring something?  
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served. Feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/sodas in the pizza cup. 

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q.  Where do I park?
A.  The driveway is the obvious spot, but eventually it will fill up on most of these game nights.  Some people do park on the street.  The soccer field parking across the street is a safe option and is the suggestion the town police gave me when I asked about overflow parking.
results.how_to_find_us: The house is just across from a soccer field.  If the driveway starts to fill up, the soccer field parking lot is a good option.

results.description:
{This popular topic has already received great feedback from other Heartbeat Salons, and now Karin and Mark are bringing it to the MetroWest area...

Shadow Work® - Discover what it is like to live from all of who you are! }

In our Heartbeat Salon this evening...

Karin and Mark, Shadow Work® facilitators, believe that our parents and our culture have encouraged us -- sometimes strongly -- to repress parts of ourselves and to believe and act as they expect. The result is that we may live our lives from a small part of who we really are, and maybe in ways that don’t really feel right.  


Tonight, they will give us an opportunity to work with four archetypal energies, which make up the human psyche: 

• Our Sovereign energy, which makes powerful choices, blesses ourselves and others, and appreciates who we each uniquely are;

• Our Magician energy, which detaches from situations, recognizes persistent patterns, and develops new solutions;

• Our Lover energy, which enables greater intimacy, connection, and creativity;

• Our Warrior energy, which clarifies our identity, helps us set healthy boundaries, and takes powerful action in the world.

To Prepare for the evening, here are some questions to consider:
• What do you want to have happen (in your life)? 
• What persistent, unwanted patterns keep repeating?
• What unwanted thoughts repeat in your mind?
• What characteristics of others really annoy you?
• What (or who) would you like to bring into your life?

Note:    Please wear comfortable, loose clothes. 

Bonus: Download the Shadow Work Basic CD. (It's free and gives an overview of their model.)

OUR LEADERS for this workshop

Mark Massoni is a PGN organizer, a Certified Shadow Work® Group Facilitator, a Shadow Work® trained coach, and a domestic and a sexual assault counselor.  He works with abusive fathers, has facilitated men's groups with the ManKind Project for over 10 years, and is a cabinet and furniture maker.

Karin Green is a Certified Shadow Work Facilitator. Karin is also a transformational life coach, assisting her clients to overcome fears, make positive changes, and create positive impact in their lives. She is a graduate of Priestess Path, Women in Power, and Women Within International. She has facilitated women's groups for 15+ years. www.shadowwidom.com

What people say about this evening...

"Fabulous work -- three experiential exercises that touched all participants deeply. Very well conceived and executed 2 hour presentation that left lecture behind to give us real revelation. Thank you Karin and Mark." ~Dennis

"Deeply emotionally moving. Felt a bit like taking part in an archeological dig... sifting through layers of stored history, unearthing feelings long buried. This is powerful work, ably and lovingly brought forward by Karin & Mark who effortlessly guided us to access inner territory and uncover gifts buried there. I was surprised by how many tears came as a result of taking part in this work. Shadow work feels like it offers the promise of deep healing work to come forth rather effortlessly."  ~Jeff

"This was a surprisingly powerful evening, and we got a delicious taste of the possibility of the Shadow Work. I love doing deep work in a safe environment, and the work we got to do in this evening has already made a difference in my life. Highest recommendation for Mark and Karin. Check it out, people! You'll be glad you did."  ~Lauren E.


Links

Most Important:

results.description:
"Annals of the Anthropocene: The Science and Policy of Earth’s Atmosphere"
Guest scientists David Keith and Steven Barrett

Meet us Monday, March 7 at 7pm at The Burren in Davis Square

David is a Professor of Applied Physics in the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences at Harvard University, and a Professor of Public Policy in the Harvard Kennedy School. His group works on climate science, energy technology, and public policy. He also helps lead Carbon Engineering, a company working on air capture of CO2.

Steven is an Associate Professor of Aeronautics and Astronautics and a Professor of Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He is the director of the Laboratory for Aviation and the Environment. His group works on the environmental impacts of aviation including atmospheric modeling and propulsion.

Science by the Pint is a monthly science cafe free and open to the public, run by the Harvard non-profit outreach group Science In The News (SITN). Read more here: http://sitn.hms.harvard.edu/science-by-the-pint/
results.name: Science by the Pint: The Science and Policy of Earth’s Atmosphere

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) at 7 PM.  We usually wait 5-10 minutes for people to show, but if you arrive later and miss us at the table,  check the small whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what the Event Host (see RSVP list) is wearing that day, and come find us on the walls.  Don't be shy, make an effort to ask around and find the group; we're all friendly.

(NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive by 7, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from cubbies, if available).

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
A weekly gathering bringing together Buddhist meditation practice and recovery. The group will meet weekly in the main practice room to:

~ Meditate with others who are in recovery or exploring recovery

~ Offer contemplations and readings which inspire our recovery and support our practices

~ Share our personal experience, strength and courage

~ Integrate the basic goodness of meditation with our commitment to recovery

'Sobriety is finding a new way of living that involves engagement where there was withdrawal; generosity where there was self-centeredness; community where there was isolation; joy where there was bitterness; trust where there was cynicism.'
  ~ Kevin Griffin, One Breath at a Time: Buddhism and the Twelve Steps

Open to all—meditation practitioners from all traditions and Twelve Step practitioners from all programs.

Leader: John R.  <a>[masked]</a>

Free/suggested donation.
results.name: Recovery Meditation

results.description:
The Buddhist Study & Meditation Group will meet every Monday at 8pm at the Common Street Spiritual Center in Natick. Please use the School Street entrance. If you go to the top floor, we are down the hall on the left, in the meditation room.

If you have your own cushion, please feel free to bring it. Otherwise, chairs and floor seats are provided. The term mindfulness has become part of our everyday language, we talk about "eating mindfully", or "trying to be more mindful in our consumer choices." Furthermore, the actual method of Mindfulness is taught in prisons and schools to reduce stress, it is taught by cognitive therapists to modify dysfunctional patterns of behavior, and it is practiced by corporate CEOs to enhance effectiveness in the workplace. In other words, we have co-opted mindfulness. We have extracted it from its original context and striped it of soteriological meaning. Worse, it has been turned into an elixir to promote the smooth functioning of our most destructive institutions. The word mindfulness comes from the Pali term sati and it is part of the eightfold path which the Buddha prescribed to end Dhaka, the stressful and disturbing mental constructions through which we view ourselves and others. Mindfulness, in this context, is the basis for insight into the true nature of reality, and according to the Buddhist tradition, when we "wake up" to the true nature of things, we realize that we are not in as bad shape as we thought. It's likened to waking up from a bad dream. Buddha is said to have become awakened through practicing mindfulness of the breath. In our weekly meetings we will practice basic mindfulness meditation and we will seek to understand how this practice fits within the framework of the Buddha's teachings. Each meeting will last about an hour and consist of brief meditation exercises and some discussion of the Buddha's radical approach to life.
results.name: Meditate and discuss the Buddha's teachings

In 2015, Comedian Steve Macone was named one of the Top 100 Comics in the country by NBC's Last Comic Standing. A cross between the life of the party and the most nervous person in the room, Macone has performed his original brand of smart, high-energy comedy at clubs and colleges around the US, England, Ireland and Canada, on Comedy Central and at the prestigious Comic's Come Home event alongside Denis Leary and Steven Wright. He's been a finalist in the Boston Comedy Festival, where he performed at the sold-out Cutler Majestic Theatre and his humor writing has appeared in world famous publications such as The Onion, New York Times, New Yorker. In 2015, he was named one of the Top 100 Comics in the country by NBC's Last Comic Standing.

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
